did.unittitle: American Society for the Extension of University Teaching records

bioghist.p: The American Society for the Extension of University Teaching (originally known as the Philadelphia Society for the Extension of University Teaching) was founded in 1890 by William Pepper, Provost of the University of Pennsylvania. The Society's aim was to extend educational opportunities to women and men who were unable to attend a university. The Wagner Free Institute of Science became involved in the University Extension movement early on in its development, with Thomas Lynch Montgomery serving briefly as the local secretary for the program.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of correspondence and speeches relating to the activities of the American Society for the Extension of University Teaching in Philadelphia from 1890 to 1892, including courses conducted at the Wagner Free Institute of Science. Also included are a few items relating to specific courses, such as an outline of a lecture and examination questions. Most of the correspondence is addressed to Thomas Lynch Montgomery.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
